bestBHT.bht: Amidst the disciples' toiling and exhaustion, they saw Jesus walking on the sea. Initially, it seemed as if He intended to pass by them silently, causing them to cry out in fear. However, Jesus had observed their struggle from a distance and understood their distress. He purposely allowed them to reach the point of exhaustion and despair before coming to their aid. Though it may have appeared that Jesus was going to pass them by, He was actually showing them that they no longer needed to strive on their own.

Henry Alford: He was about to pass by them. He intended so to do. But what man could say this? Who knoweth the mind of Christ but the Spirit of God?" (Wordsw)
would has here but a faint subjective reference, and is well expressed by the English phrase in the text." (Commentary)
this 'would have passed by' and the 'willingly received him' of John vi. 21, mutually explain one another." (Lange)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He 'saw' this from His mountain top, and through the darkness of the night, for His heart was all with them: yet would He not go to their relief till His own time came.

So when they had rowed about five and twenty or thirty furlongs... in eight or nine hours they had only made some three and a half miles. By this time, therefore, they must have been in a state of exhaustion and despondency bordering on despair; and now at length, having tried them long enough.
He cometh unto them, walking upon the sea... and would have passed by them—but only in the sense of Luke 24:28; Genesis 32:26; Genesis 18:3; Genesis 18:5; Genesis 42:7.
Philip Schaff: Distressed in rowing. Lit., ‘tormented.’ In consequence of the contrary wind.
Would have passed by them. Mentioned by Mark only: This was to try them.
This passing on was, as it were, to show them the way, to show that they need no longer toil to meet Him at eastern Bethsaida, but might pass directly over.
Archibald T. Robertson: He wished to pass by them, praeterire eos.
Cried out, a shriek of terror, or scream.
John Gill: He saw them either with his bodily eyes from the mountain on which he was; or he perceived in his Spirit, he knew, by virtue of his omniscience as God, what distress his disciples were in.
they were in the utmost pain and uneasiness of mind, as well as fatigue of body, assisting the men in rowing
it looked as though he intended to have gone by them, and said nothing to them, though this was far from his real design.
John Wesley: And he saw them — For the darkness could veil nothing from him.
And would have passed by them — That is, walked, as if he was passing by.

bhtAttempts.bht: In the midst of their toiling and distress, the disciples spotted Jesus walking on the sea. It seemed as though He intended to pass by them without saying a word, causing them to cry out in fear and desperation. However, Jesus had seen their struggle from His vantage point on the mountain and knew the state of their hearts. He was testing them, allowing them to experience exhaustion and despair before coming to their aid at the appointed time. Though it may have appeared that Jesus was going to pass them by, He was actually showing them that they no longer needed to toil and meet Him on their own efforts. Jesus was there, seeing their every struggle and ready to bring them comfort and rescue.

In their exhausting and desperate state, the disciples saw Jesus walking on the sea. It seemed as though He intended to pass by them silently, intensifying their fear and anguish. But from His vantage point on the mountain, Jesus saw their struggle and understood their hearts. He wanted to test them, allowing them to reach the point of despair before coming to their aid. Although it appeared that Jesus would pass them by, He was actually demonstrating that they no longer needed to strive on their own, as He was there to bring them comfort and rescue.

In the midst of their toiling and distress, the disciples spotted Jesus walking on the sea. It seemed as though He intended to pass by them without saying a word, causing them to cry out in fear and desperation. However, Jesus had seen their struggle and knew the state of their hearts. He was testing them, allowing them to experience exhaustion and despair before coming to their aid at the appointed time. Though it may have appeared that Jesus was going to pass them by, He was actually showing them that they no longer needed to toil and meet Him on their own efforts. Jesus was there, seeing their every struggle and ready to bring them comfort and rescue.

Amidst the disciples' toiling and exhaustion, they saw Jesus walking on the sea. Initially, it seemed as if He intended to pass by them silently, causing them to cry out in fear. However, Jesus had observed their struggle from a distance and understood their distress. He purposely allowed them to reach the point of exhaustion and despair before coming to their aid. Though it may have appeared that Jesus was going to pass them by, He was actually showing them that they no longer needed to strive on their own.

In their state of exhaustion and despair, the disciples spotted Jesus walking on the sea. It seemed as though He intended to pass them by without acknowledging their plight, invoking fear and distress. However, Jesus had seen their struggle and knew their hearts. He was testing them, allowing them to experience hardship before coming to their aid. Despite the appearance that Jesus was going to ignore them, He was actually showing them that they no longer needed to rely solely on their own efforts. Jesus was there to bring them comfort and rescue.
